channel.title: Of splines and men
channel.description:
While splines are a great way to make mouse movement [i]look[/i] more realistic ask yourself this question: Can I be fooled by splines? If you can watch a mouse and tell the difference between a [i]human[/i]-powered mouse and a [i]spline[/i]-powered mouse do you think they can too?
Remember, the game can be recorded and played back with a bit of work (on our side) and with ease (on their side). I know, for a fact, that client recording has been done (I have done it and wL has done it). Despite what you may think, the recorded playback files are very small compared to an AVI or mpeg of the same length of time.
With this in mind, splines are nice, but they look hilarious if not done perfectly. If you don't believe me, use snagit or some other recording software to watch your own mouse movements and tell me you don't chuckle a little when you play it back. (of course if you have the client playback implemented use that :) )

item.title: Of splines and men
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I can see how using Moparscape as a vector to collect human-like (well, moparscapian-like :/) mouse movements is useful, but IMO talking about storing a ton of movements and transforming them is the wrong way to go about this.

Read full topic

item.title: Of splines and men
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

How about a database that contains all splines sorted by user id, that is accessible only by the bots?
It would select a random user id, and use that pool for the splines.

Read full topic

item.title: Of splines and men
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

how about include a bunch of splines. have an option to specify the number to use. then for the more paranoid user give them the option to record their own. when it runs select the user ones first and if that pool isnt big enough then use the default ones.

Read full topic

item.title: Of splines and men
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

Yeah, each player should have to ‘record’ splines. It should be a function of the bot. However, I disagree that they would ‘catch up with it’ as speedster said. I think the fact that you apply random transforms to the splines is enough to stop that happening.

Read full topic

item.title: Of splines and men
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

If you keep track of mouse movements belonging to one specific person, you can actually emulate him in your bot, which makes it less detectable then random mouse movements I though about this idea a few months ago, but found it hard to implement because you can’t easily get mouse movements. Implementing it in moparscape would be a perfect way to do it.

Read full topic

item.title: Of splines and men
item.dc:creator: @speedster239 speedster239
item.description:
@speedster239 wrote:

sppt:

For collecting human mouse movement, how about something like sleepwalker, which you would just run in the background and record how you move your mouse? That way you could easily get millions of movements.

[quote=“speedster239, post:60, topic:293489”]This is theoretically possible, but practically it won’t survive. Scaling human movements which don’t follow any predictable pattern or formula, or law, will work in time, but a computer can catch up if these scaled movements are read from a database. The bottom line is unless you know what goes on on their end you’re in the dark. Eventually they’ll map out these movements script-for-script if necessary, and create an exception for them as well.

Depending on the field of application, publicly available bots like RSBot are at risk of Jagex just picking apart whatever system it uses right from the code itself. However, in a large scale this could work…

Gathering movements, of say users of the program itself on the fly, scaling them like you say right then and there, and using them in working scripts, or the scripts of others users by communicating through a server, could cover Jagex being able to detect hard coded systems.

This vaguely reminds me of http://kaitnieks.com/SleepWalker/, or at least the way it handles program-user to program-user interaction for some mutual benefit.

Probably too far fetched, but definitely the first thing that came to mind.[/quote]

Moparisthebest, I like the idea of incorporating it into the Mopar client, you’d be able to collect tons of data really quickly.

Read full topic

For collecting human mouse movement, how about something like sleepwalker, which you would just run in the background and record how you move your mouse? That way you could easily get millions of movements.

item.title: Of splines and men
item.dc:creator: @D_e_n_v_e_r D e n v e r
item.description:
@D_e_n_v_e_r wrote:

sppt:

For collecting human mouse movement, how about something like sleepwalker, which you would just run in the background and record how you move your mouse? That way you could easily get millions of movements.

That doesn’t work unfortunately , if you calculated that using probability in maths, you’d almost get an infinite number.
imagine you have to record movements of mouse to any pixel from any pixel, now that is a big calculation.

but if you meant like just collecting few millions of curves to be stretched or compressed later on to form the path wich will connect two points, then that is not a bad idea.

Read full topic

item.title: Of splines and men
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

speedster239:

Thought I should note…What about Jagex being able to view what’s running on your machine, or even if that’s not possible, what’s running in the JVM. They see a malicious process, for example “WhateverBot”, and that should raise a red flag. It seems like everybody jumps through hoops with all of these anti-detection systems, when in reality it could be as simple as 1-2-3 for them…This seems simple, and something along the lines of what I would do in their position. Not that would I would do matters.

Good questions, you should always be thinking about what they could possibly do and what you should do. However, if your bot runs the unsigned client in a sandbox just like a real browser would (with a proper SecurityManager) they can’t do any type of detection like this, so you don’t have to worry about it.

Read full topic

item.title: Of splines and men
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

speedster239:

Thought I should note…What about Jagex being able to view what’s running on your machine, or even if that’s not possible, what’s running in the JVM. They see a malicious process, for example “WhateverBot”, and that should raise a red flag. It seems like everybody jumps through hoops with all of these anti-detection systems, when in reality it could be as simple as 1-2-3 for them…This seems simple, and something along the lines of what I would do in their position. Not that would I would do matters.

Except, once they see a bot process being run, they need to notify the server. It wouldn’t take long for bot makers to find that packet and prevent it from ever being sent.

Read full topic

They see a malicious process, for example “WhateverBot”, and that should raise a red flag. item.title: Of splines and men
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“speedster239, post:60, topic:293489”][quote author=BAsh link=topic=388347.msg2939538#msg2939538 date=1251767899]
I think hard coding them is a terrible idea. That said:

You can apply a magnification factor and stretch them in one or both directions. You can rotate them. You don’t have to stay on screen.

Perhaps get 200 or so (more would be better). For each determine the distance traveled so you don’t scale them so much that they’re meaningless. Then choose one, any one, and rotate / scale to fit.

The fact that you don’t have a path but a series of non-contiguous data points is annoying.
[/quote]

This is theoretically possible, but practically it won’t survive. Scaling human movements which don’t follow any predictable pattern or formula, or law, will work in time, but a computer can catch up if these scaled movements are read from a database. The bottom line is unless you know what goes on on their end you’re in the dark. Eventually they’ll map out these movements script-for-script if necessary, and create an exception for them as well.

Depending on the field of application, publicly available bots like RSBot are at risk of Jagex just picking apart whatever system it uses right from the code itself. However, in a large scale this could work…

Gathering movements, of say users of the program itself on the fly, scaling them like you say right then and there, and using them in working scripts, or the scripts of others users by communicating through a server, could cover Jagex being able to detect hard coded systems.[/quote]

You aren’t going to do something stupid like hard code 200 mouse methods to choose from and release it in a public bot. I am talking about recording thousands upon thousands of mouse movements, and on runtime, the program could pick a certain number of random ones for itself, then from them choose the ones to modify and use. Jagex couldn’t possibly detect a system such as this that relies only on randomness and a continually growing database of actual human mouse movements.

Read full topic

item.title: Of splines and men
item.dc:creator: @Uriko Uriko
item.description:
@Uriko wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:56, topic:293489”]For some perspective, think about what you would do to detect bots and from there code defensively. The point is that in this game of cat and mouse they have the upper hand. Splines alone are only going to give you a believable path. Fitts law will likely keep you from being automatically detected and possibly, in isolation, your singular action may not arouse suspicion but if you rely on fitts and clever splines alone your actions, taken as a whole over 60 seconds, will be condemning to the point of hilarity.[/quote]/me saw what you had before edit

it was quite lulzy.

Read full topic

[quote=“BAsh, post:45, topic:293489”]I think hard coding them is a terrible idea. That said:

You can apply a magnification factor and stretch them in one or both directions. You can rotate them. You don’t have to stay on screen.

Perhaps get 200 or so (more would be better). For each determine the distance traveled so you don’t scale them so much that they’re meaningless. Then choose one, any one, and rotate / scale to fit.

The fact that you don’t have a path but a series of non-contiguous data points is annoying.[/quote]

This is theoretically possible, but practically it won’t survive. Scaling human movements which don’t follow any predictable pattern or formula, or law, will work in time, but a computer can catch up if these scaled movements are read from a database. The bottom line is unless you know what goes on on their end you’re in the dark. Eventually they’ll map out these movements script-for-script if necessary, and create an exception for them as well.

Depending on the field of application, publicly available bots like RSBot are at risk of Jagex just picking apart whatever system it uses right from the code itself. However, in a large scale this could work…

Gathering movements, of say users of the program itself on the fly, scaling them like you say right then and there, and using them in working scripts, or the scripts of others users by communicating through a server, could cover Jagex being able to detect hard coded systems.

This vaguely reminds me of http://kaitnieks.com/SleepWalker/, or at least the way it handles program-user to program-user interaction for some mutual benefit.

Probably too far fetched, but definitely the first thing that came to mind.

item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

For some perspective, think about what you would do to detect bots and from there code defensively. The point is that in this game of cat and mouse they have the upper hand. Splines alone are only going to give you a believable path. Fitts law will likely keep you from being automatically detected and possibly, in isolation, your singular action may not arouse suspicion but if you rely on fitts and clever splines alone your actions, taken as a whole over 60 seconds, will be condemning to the point of hilarity.
